docs.lead_paragraph: A couple sits across from me in my clinic. Holding hands and grinning widely, the woman tells me that she tested positive on a home pregnancy test. This joyful conversation goes on in doctors' offices thousands of times a day. As a pediatrician, however, it is rarely news I am overjoyed to hear. Both of these parents-to-be are under age 17. Each year more than a million American teenagers become pregnant. Four out of 10 opt for abortion. Fewer than a third of teenage mothers finish high school. Their babies have a higher risk of low-birth weight and its many complications. These dismal facts were hardly abstractions to me; children having children have always been a part of my practice and I have necessarily worked through this one patient at a time.

headline.main: Data Can't Diagnose the Human Condition

docs.abstract: Dr Howard Markel column on treating teenager who chose to become pregnant despite being HIV positive; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In hindsight, Debbie McDowell now realizes that the quirks and idiosyncrasies her son Jake displayed when he was very young were the first warnings of an illness that would eventually debilitate her child and test her own mettle as a parent. Jake would wear only shoes with Velcro closures that he could pull tight and his pants had to have skin-tight legs. Little kids do bizarre things, she told herself. What's the harm in indulging him?

headline.main: Finding Hope Amid Despair in Treating Compulsive Disorders

docs.abstract: New research indicates that 2 to 3 percent of population suffers from obsessive-compulsive disorder, which often goes undiagnosed for years as sufferers hide symptoms; doctors have made progress in understanding and treating disorder, characterized by persistent, distressing thoughts or images and accompanying ritual behaviors or mental acts; do not yet known cause, but have identified likely site of problem in brain; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A 3-year-old girl who was sexually abused by a male relative became afraid of all men, including her own father, who was not the abuser. A college student who was abused by a teacher in high school would not ask questions in class or talk to the professor for fear she would be noticed and the abuse would happen again.
docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on post-traumatic stress disorder; disorder, readily diagnosed in adults who survive well-recognized traumas, often has more suble roots in children and takes on symptoms that are easily confused with other conditions; graph of estimated risk of developing disorder for victims of certain traumas (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Lifting weights just two or three times a week can reduce blood pressure, body fat levels and improve glucose metabolism, according to an American Heart Association survey. The survey, published in the Feb. 22 issue of the journal Circulation, reported findings from a panel of cardiovascular experts selected by the heart association.

headline.main: A Lifting Regimen for a Healthier Heart

docs.abstract: American Heart Association survey finds that lifting weights just two or three times a week can reduce blood pressure and body fat levels and improve glucose metabolism; survey is based on findings of panel of cardiovascular experts, who reviewed studies by other researchers; panel finds weight lifting can be beneficial to some patients recovering from heart attacks (M)
docs.snippet: Lifting weights just two or three times a week can reduce blood pressure, body fat levels and improve glucose metabolism, according to an American Heart Association survey.    The survey, published in the Feb. 22 issue of the journal Circulation,...

docs.lead_paragraph: In a startling discovery that could radically alter the way asthma patients are monitored and treated, doctors at the University of Virginia have found that the breath of asthmatics who are having an attack is a thousand times as acidic as normal. This increase in acidity -- never before detected in asthma patients -- may be central to the disease process, the researchers said. While it is not yet known what causes the imbalance, the finding could open an entirely new avenue of research to explain the disease.

headline.main: Acidic Breath of Asthmatics Hints at Better Treatments

docs.abstract: University of Virgina doctors report that breath of asthmatics is thousand times as acidic as normal during attacks; finding could radically alter way asthma patients are monitored and treated; researchers say increased acidity may be central to disease process (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Louis Weinstein, a founder of the modern medical specialty of infectious diseases and a leading medical educator, died on Thursday at a nursing home near his home in Newton, Mass. He was 92. ''He put clinical infectious diseases on the map and made it a very strong specialty,'' said Dr. Robert G. Petersdorf, another pioneer in infectious diseases at the University of Washington in Seattle and a former president of the Association of American Medical Colleges.
docs.abstract: Dr Louis Weinstein, founder of modern medical specialty of infectious-diseases and leading medical educator, dies at age 92 (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: During the war, the Allies so feared the possibility of a German bomb that they sent Moe Berg, a baseball catcher, linguist and spy, to attend a scientific lecture that the Nazi government allowed Heisenberg to give in Zurich in 1944. Berg was to take out a pistol he was carrying and shoot Heisenberg dead if he gave any hint that he was building a bomb. Heisenberg restricted his talk to an abstruse topic called S-matrix theory, according to the David C. Cassidy book ''Uncertainty'' (W. H. Freeman, 1992). But at dinner, in response to a barbed assertion from a Swiss physicist that Germany had all but lost the war, Heisenberg retorted, ''It would have been so beautiful if we had won.''

headline.main: An Abstruse Topic Saved His Life

docs.abstract: Allies reportedly sent Moe Berg, baseball catcher, linguist and spy, to scientific lecture given by Werner Heisenberg in Zurich in 1944 with instructions to kill Heisenberg if he indicated he was working on atomic bomb for Nazi Germany; Heisenberg, who spoke on abstruse topic, quipped years later that he owed his survival to difficulty of topic; photo (S)
